item.value: By 2008 there were almost 1.3 billion telephone lines in the world.
The explosion of Mount Tambora, on Sumbawa island, Indonesia in 1815 was heard 2,600 km (1,600 mi) away and has been called the loudest sound ever heard by humans.
China has more than 350 million telephones, the most of any other country. The United States is second with 268 million.
The blue whale is the largest known animal on Earth. Mature blue whales can measure anywhere from 75 feet (23 m) to 100 feet (30.5 m) long and can weigh as much as 150 tons.
The longest word in a major English dictionary is 'Pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis'.
The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean in the world. It covers about 1/3 of its surface. It is 155.557 million sq km.
About two thirds of the Earth's surface is covered with water.
The Sputnik 1, launched on October 4, 1957 by Russia, was the first human-made object to orbit the Earth.
There are more than 2,700 languages in the world.
Sound travels at a speed of around 767 miles per hour (1,230 kilometres per hour).
The moon orbits the Earth every 27.32 days
The biggest earthquake ever recorded occurred in Chile, in 1960. Known as the Great Chilean Earthquake, the quake measured 9.5 on the Richter scale.
The original Olympic Games were a series of athletic competitions held in Ancient Greece.
Drinking too much water too quickly can lead to water intoxication which causes an imbalance of water in the brain
Alaska is the largest state in America.
A sneeze generates a wind of 166 km/hr (100 mi/hr), and a cough moves out at 100 km/hr (60 mi/hr).
The blue whale can produce the loudest sound of any living animal. The sound can be detected as far away as 530 miles.
The earliest dated printed book is the "Diamond Sutra", printed in China almost 3,000 thousand years ago.
The earth is the 3rd planet from the sun and is the 5th largest planet in our solar system.
Roughly 70 percent of an adult's body is made up of water.
